messageBody:
Hi Cedric,

I agree with you. A scripting language would be the most flexible way to
support every kind of "rule". Inventing an own language would definitely
make NO sense.

From a JUnit perspective, there should be some arguments in mind:

- JUnit tends to avoid references to external libraries
- Any additional jars to be used for running tests will confuse people
(which jars has to be included ?)
- Any 3rdParty library would increase distribution volume. OK, BeanShell
core is about 120k (compared to JUnit 4 with about 600k) , no really
convincing argument ;-)

The use cases I had in past are almost based on:
- standard rules like "server available", "DB available", "DB filled with
test data", ...
- existence of any files and or configurations

Either this "rules" are shared, common code in some helper classes, or are
dependent on current test setup (e.g. DB connection), where I implement this
rule in context of current test case (reusing existing code).

Using script only code will result in more distributed logic, which may be
more difficult to maintain. And some predefined rules like date checks,
platform configuration will even support widely used rules with a very easy
to understand syntax,

Jochen

A more flexible way to address this is to use a scripting language.

TestNG allows you to define such clauses in BeanShell, so that, for
example,
if you want certain tests to run on weekends only, you would use the
following code:

<test name="Basic" >
<script language="beanshell"><![CDATA[
int today = Calendar.getInstance().
get(Calendar.DAY_OF_WEEK);
return today == Calendar.SATURDAY ||
today == Calendar.SUNDAY;
]]></script>

You can also do more fun stuff, like asking the user if they wish to run
each test method with a Swing dialog (more details
here<http://beust.com/weblog/archives/000325.html>
).

BeanShell is very cool and very simple to integrate in your applications,
I
strongly recommend using it instead of reinventing your own expression
language.

--
Cedric
http://testng.org

On 10/13/06, Jochen Hiller <jo.hiller@...> wrote:
>
> I posted some months ago an enhancement request [1] for a
> @Prerequisite annotation,
> which should specify tests to be run only if a given precondition (via a
> call to a specified Java method). It could also be represented as a
> @Ignore(whenNot="someBooleanConditionMethod")
> notation.
>
> The semantics expressed with @Ignore and @Prerequisite is different:
> Ignore
> means exclude this test given on a condition, whereas @Prerequisite has
an
> include semantics when condition is fulfilled, which is for some cases
> easier to understand.
>
> There is an implementation available for a @Prerequsite tag [2]. It will
> call the given Java method, and if expression is NOT fulfilled, throw an
> Ignore... exception, so it will be known by all listeners as an ignored
> test.
>
> I also thought about, whether to support different platform as
predefined
> rules something like
>
> @Prerequiste(platform="i386") # architecture
> @Prerequiste(platform="linux") # operation system
> @Prerequiste(platform="macos") # operation system
> @Prerequiste(platform="jdk14") # JDK versions
> @Prerequiste(platform="gtk") # UI platform
> @Prerequiste(platform="win32") # UI platform
>
> (like platform ARCH, OS, WS, NL, will be used in Eclipse).
>
> Regards, Jochen
